coverImage.title: Me fenced in as a little kid
coverImage.alt: Spoiler: I didn't like being fenced in as a kid.

content.value: Hey, my name's Andrew. This is a story about my life—but it's a story about your life, too. Five years ago, I graduated from a liberal arts college with a fancy degree and $50,000 in student loan debt...sound familiar?

If you're like me, you probably landed a full-time job where you could work the "right" hours, earn the "right" amount of money, and gain the "right" experience. Maybe you even made the "right" move by quitting to start your own business.
But after living the "A Life" for years...
Are you as creative as you'd like to be?
As productive?
As motivated?
Are you even happy?
Are you even free?
Or are you still stuck—like a tiny cog in a huge machine?
You can be more than a cog.

While escaping the 9–5 world can be a great first step toward actual freedom, a lot of freelancers find themselves even more trapped and even less happy than when they were working a corporate gig. How is that possible?
I'll tell you. It's all about the "lines."

Lines are rules. They're the social guard rails, the things you're "supposed" to do—the tracks you're expected to follow because that's "just the way things are." These lines are meant to make us feel safe and normal: if you just keep your head down and work hard enough, everything will be alright.
We both know that's bullshit.
Studies consistently show that most Americans are living paycheck–to–paycheck: in 2016, nearly half the people surveyed by the Federal Reserve Board said they would have a hard time coming up with
$400 to pay for an emergency

If you and I continue going down the same beaten path, we're going to spend the rest of our lives trading time for money, until we have been ground into the earth by the weight of other people's success—like that guy in the sandwich line wearing a back brace and wrist guard just to make it through the day.
It doesn't matter whether you're a CEO or a sandwich-maker. If you keep following the "lines," if you keep chasing the "A Life," you will always be just
making it through the day
. Because, frankly, the working world is DESIGNED to squeeze every last ounce of energy and productivity out of you—while someone else reaps the profit.
Fuck that. Fuck the lines.

title.en-US: Andrew carrying his bike through BNO

description.en-US: Andrew carrying his bike through BNO

content.value: What is F the Lines, really?

Finance buffs will teach you how to make money. Creative experts will help you improve your technical skills. Business gurus will advise you on starting a business. But most of the resources available to you are focused on making you better at FOLLOWING the rules.
Where can you go to learn how to break them? Who can help you combine all that raw experience and knowledge into a kind of life that doesn't exist yet?
I don't have all the answers.
But I created F the Lines to find them.
Let's go on an expedition.

Over the next four months (April 1st to August 1st), I'm going to be posting weekly articles on creativity, productivity, and happiness—with the end-goal of publishing a simple framework that anyone can use to create a nonconventional business and lifestyle. For anyone tuning in later, that's OK. I'll send you the backlog.

If you want to come along with me, you can subscribe below to get weekly articles with 100% actionable insights and tips. Sound helpful? Keep reading, I'm going to cover the topics I have planned and share a few articles to get you started.

name.en-US: FTL Framework Subscribe Form (Context = Intro Article)

teaser.en-US: Get weekly insights sent straight to your inbox. No bullshit, just 100% actionable advice.

content.value: The FTL Roadmap

When I said I don't have the answers, I meant it. What I do have is questions. I'm going to explore one of those questions each week and share the results until I accomplish my personal goals: buying and converting a camper van, starting a podcast, and switching to life on the road (more on this in my blueprint article next week).
Weekly Topics
How do I create a

title.en-US: Creative Block Almost Killed Me: Here's How You Can Slay It

summary.en-US: The following is a story about how creative block nearly killed me. And even more importantly, five steps you can use to annihilate it for good.

content.value: How many times have you Googled the phrase "creative block" in your life? How many times this month? This week? I've lost count. And judging by the 930 million results that search returns, being stuck (creatively) is a problem that a bunch of other people are struggling with, too. It fucking sucks. I know.
The Downward Spiral

Back in July of 2016, I was living at home—I had impulsively quit my full-time job as a copywriter earlier that year to start my own design company. Things were going pretty well, and I was taking on every project that came my way.
One of my clients was looking to publish an illustrated book at the time, so naturally I said yes. Mind you, I was a web designer, and hadn't
really
illustrated much of anything, let alone designed an entire book. But screw it. I can totally do this!

Shocker...a few weeks into the project, it was starting to feel like I totally could NOT "do this." I was overwhelmed by all the things I needed to learn in order to deliver the final product, but there was an even bigger problem: creative block had set in—badly. Just sitting down at the computer was painful. My illustrations looked like shit (to me), and the harder I tried to find inspiration, the more resistant my brain became to providing any kind of creative energy.

Around the same time, my cousin-in-law (who I had just seen in Utah) was placed in hospice and a family friend committed suicide, which was the final straw. I fell into total burnout mode: ignoring emails, playing video games, binging TV series, reading design "inspiration" articles, and arguing mindlessly about politics on Reddit 24/7. Basically, doing anything and everything I could think of to jump start my creative process.
This culminated in what I can only describe as "the worst day of my life."

I hadn't eaten anything or moved from my spot on the living room for the past five hours. I hadn't talked to anyone or left the house in...fuck, I have no clue how long. My phone was on, but only because I knew that if I turned it off someone would think I was dead—which would mean police. Which would mean interacting with the outside world.

Around that time, a car pulled into the driveway. I remember my first thought being, "Oh shit...THEY FOUND ME." Which is kind of funny in retrospect, because, like...who did I think was after me? I was a designer running late on a small illustration project, not Tom Cruise dodging taser-wielding agents in
Minority Report
I high-tailed it to my room, and put some serious thought to
jumping

hopping out the back window. It wasn't the cops (taser-wielding or otherwise). It turned out to be my ex-professor/creative partner's son, who she had sent over to check on me. Nonetheless, I knew there would be more humans where that one came from...none of whom I cared to confront, let alone carry out a conversation with.

I threw my bike in the back of my car and headed over to the local library. Why the library, you ask? Well, the plan, as I recall, was to drop my car off at the nearest parking lot then bike back to my house so I could make it look like I wasn't home and buy some time while I gathered any essential belongings that would be accompanying me on my escape to the forest, where I would live happily ever after and never wrestle with creativity again.
It was a beautiful plan.

Sadly, or maybe fortunately, I didn't make it two blocks before a cop car rolled around the corner and flagged me down. Like Tom Cruise, I was ready to fucking run. But I somehow managed to play it cool (enough).
No, I hadn't realized people were trying to get in touch with me for weeks...yes, I'll call them back...me, I'm fine...oh, the bike? I was just...uh, going for a bike...ride...nice day, isn't it?

The cop eventually drove off, and I was left idling in the middle of the road—a fitting metaphor for my current outlook on life. I started mentally backpedaling though the chain of events that had led to this moment. Like
Theoden trapped at Helm's Deep
, beset by a massive army of Uruk-hai, desolately wondering: "How did it come to this?" And more importantly, what was I going to do about it?

title.en-US: Theoden: How did it come to this?

content.value: The Road Back
I wish I could say I learned a hard, swift lesson from that experience. But the truth is, while I did start to take my mental/emotional
health
wellbeing more seriously, creative block continued to haunt me on a daily basis, and it took the better part of three years to distill my mistakes into an effective solution.
That's what I'm going to share with you now: a bullet-proof, battle-tested strategy to slay creative block once and for all.
Step 1: Define Creative Block
"To defeat your enemy, you must first know your enemy." —Sun Tzu
Actually, Sun Tzu didn't say that. But it sounds like something he might say, and I don't want to get sidetracked by Googling a real quote right now. (We're trying to stay creative, remember?)
You see, I think people get
wayyy
to fancy with their definition of creative block: it's a lack of inspiration, it's self-doubt, it's negative self-talk, it's rejection anxiety...
Fuck all that. I'll tell you what creative block is; it's very simple:
Creative block is a shortage of mental energy that results from consistently inputting more than you output.

This is a highly effective place to start when diagnosing your creative woes. Try saying it out loud: "I am tired and uncreative because I have input more that I have output today." How did that feel? Does the problem seem slightly more manageable now? Good, let's keep going.
Step 2: List Your Mental Earning and Spending

I used to think that my brain was magical—that I had an unlimited supply of energy, which could be drawn upon endlessly without fail. This was/is clearly not true. So, when you try to understand what's causing your creative block, it can be really helpful to divide your day-to-day activities into two categories: mental earning and mental spending.
Mental Earning:

the act of producing or changing something. Designing a landing page, writing a blog post, playing the drums, or even organizing your room. By definition, you have been creative by doing one of these things—there is an immediate benefit.
Mental Spending:

refers to passive stuff, like watching YouTube videos, browsing Reddit, listening to a podcast, or shopping on Amazon. You may pick up inspiration from these things, but they don't benefit you until you act on that inspiration.

Now that you're aware of these two categories, what I want you to do is grab a piece of paper and write down all the things that give you energy on one side and all the things that drain your energy on the other side. Here are a few of mine:

title.en-US: My energy draining and giving activities

content.value: Step 3: Shed the Dead Weight
Ok, you've got your list. Next, you're going to
Marie Kondo
this list by killing off anything that's not helping you progress as a creative human. For each item on the "Draining" side of your list, ask yourself one question:
Does this thing
actually
make my life better, or does it just
feel
that way?

When going through this process, it's essential to only consider the cold hard facts because "sugary" addictions will try to justify their existence in very sneaky ways. For example, when I stopped using dating apps, I could hear this little voice in my head protesting: "But you're missing out on all these opportunities to meet people!"

Dating apps make us feel good in the moment by showing lots of pictures of attractive people (it's basically micro-porn). But over the past three years, I've probably spent hundreds of hours on Tinder, OkCupid, et al., and I have only one very mediocre date to show for it. I've literally gotten better results by hanging out at my local climbing gym for five minutes!

When you add up how much time these "feel-good" pursuits suck up on a daily basis (with no tangible benefits) it's absolutely staggering. That's why you need to be super-ruthless in hunting them down and jettisoning them from your life before they suck you dry. Take your list and nail it to the wall, if necessary!
Step 4: Redefine "Creative" and "Output"
You're familiar with the
punishing inner critic

, right? It's that little voice in your head that says    everything you create is garbage and everything you accomplish is not enough. Well, if you're really serious about sticking to the list you just made, you need to confront that voice—or it's  going to keep making you miserable.

The simplest way to disarm your inner critic is to redefine the words "creative" and "output." Firstly, let's expand the kind of work we deem to be creative. I'm not advising you to lower your ambitions, but, rather, to take note of the many small wins that would normally fly under the radar.

Say you're spinning your wheels on a logo design—it feels like you haven't done anything creative all day. Instead of comparing that work against the best logo you've ever made, readjust your mental "zoom" to only cover the designs you're currently working on. From that perspective, one or two iterations will stand out as more creative than the others. And, voila! You've suddenly "done" something creative by retroactively changing your standards. You can then use that small rush of inspiration to slingshot you toward an even better iteration.

Similarly, you're not going to have the same level of energy every day, so it's emotionally toxic to expect the same level of output at all times. If you find yourself mentally exhausted before you've finished breakfast (the struggle is real), scale back the list of things you want to accomplish. You might end up doing more than you thought you could, and adding extra items to a to-do list is way more empowering than struggling to complete one that feels like it's a mile long.
Step 5: Stay Vigilant

Money is much easier to spend than earn; your brain is no different. If want to keep creative block at bay, you need to be mindful of the different ways that it can slither back into your life. It's like Mad-Eye Moody says: "Constant vigilance!" I think there are basically four ways to do this—although feel free to adopt more strategies as you go.
Emotional Zagging

Disappointment and frustration are the two of the biggest culprits behind creative block. When I started to feel trapped by the illustration project, I should have taken a breather to assess the situation and figure out what the best course of action was. Instead, I pushed myself to the point of emotional burnout, then went on a mental spending tear to try and distract from the pain of creative block.

Now, whenever I get a pang of anxiety, I do an "emotional zag," which essentially means taking negative energy and using it to slingshot you in an opposite (positive) direction. Energy is energy, after all. So, when I feel the urge to erase an especially brutal round of logo revisions by aimlessly swiping on Tinder, I go straight out for a run instead.
Stick to the Mission

UX design has made the platforms and apps we use so fucking "convenient" that a five-second search on Google can (and will) turn into three hours of binge-watching cat videos on YouTube. Always, ALWAYS, have a singular, achievable mission when you dive into social media. Once you find the information you need, bail
immediately
. You can even set a timer on your phone and write your objective down on a piece of paper, if necessary.
Maintain an Input / Output Ratio

I find I'm the happiest and most creative when I spend 90% of my time creating and 10% learning or browsing for inspiration—anything below 75% is getting into the danger zone. When you find a balance that works for you, post it on your wall or somewhere you'll see it often. Do a mental check throughout the day to make sure you're in the clear.
Create Your Own Rulebook
I have a Daily Log database in
Notion

(more on this in another post) where I track personal stats, one of those being a "Rules Broken" field that lists any personal rules that I broke that day—No screens after 10pm, Get out of bed instantly, etc. You don't have to get this fancy; your rule log might just be a simple list scrawled on the back cover of your notebook. But whichever method you choose, keeping track of your slip-ups can help you see when something is becoming a negative pattern.
Alright, that's it.

You now have all the weapons you need to slay creative block for good. It won't be easy, but if you follow these five steps, you'll be amazed by how quickly it slithers back to the dark, dismal hole it came from. If you want to drop a comment or question, head over to the article link on Reddit. Be well, everyone.

title.en-US: 10 Million You's: The Hidden Benefits of Dying Every Day

summary.en-US: Making the right decisions every day is hard. A simple trick you can easily implement is dividing each moment into different "selves," aka dying.

content.value: It was the sushi that killed me. In that first bite, I suddenly realized that I was dead. And not only that—I was about to die again.
Ok, that intro was super-harsh. Let me rewind a bit.
Theseus
While I was going to
Ithaca

for my first two years of college, I developed this addiction to philosophy. Even then, I knew it was pretty much useless (in the sense of directly repaying my $50k of student loan debt). But I couldn't help myself.
I was particularly interested in thought experiments: outlandish scenarios that philosophers devise to illustrate a certain problem or theory. One of my all-time favorites is the
Ship of Theseus
. It goes something like this:

Suppose a ship sailed by the Greek hero Theseus is kept in a harbor as a museum piece. Over time, some of the wooden parts begin to rot—and after a century or so, all of the parts have been replaced. Is it still the "same" ship?
This is a direct analogy to human identity, aka: "Am I the same person I was ten years ago? Will I be the same person in twenty years?" The comfortable answer is
yes
, but I'm going to ask you to do something strange. I'm going to ask you to start dying with me. Ready? Let's do this.
The Day of a Thousand Deaths

Back to the sushi. I don't normally make profound existential discoveries while eating seaweed and rice, but on this particular Friday, I was late to work, and those sushi rolls were literally the only thing standing between me and a four-hour shift of selling shoes on an empty stomach.

Back then (ok, you got me...it was like a year ago), I was cooking spaghetti for 50% of my dinners and rarely making more than a single serving at a time, so it was a pleasant surprise to find myself pre-stocked for once.

In that moment, I felt a kind of gratitude—not to "myself," but to a former version of myself who had spent time to make the sushi. That Andrew (yesterday at 5pm Andrew) would never get to enjoy the fruits of his labor. He had sacrificed short-term pleasure to make life better for a future self.

It was weirdly heroic. And that feeling of heroism (I'll call it "self-patriotism") changed how I looked at my life. By separating myself into many "selves" that were constantly dying and being born in every moment, I gained a deeper respect for how my decisions affected the person I would become.
Like Ryan Gosling in
Blade Runner 2049
, when you decide to start giving up meaningless in-the-moment temptations, it allows you to shift your entire life into a higher gear—to live for a greater purpose.
Dying for the right cause is the most human thing we can do.

title.en-US: Blade Runner 2049: Dying for the right cause

description.en-US: Blade Runner 2049: Dying for the right cause is the most human thing we can do.

content.value: Becoming a Self-Patriot
I think you'll probably agree that it's easier to advocate for someone else than to stand up for yourself. I'm reminded of
this video
, where Maryia Bulka (an artist/designer) is struggling to raise her prices.
Chris Do (a business coach) asks her to pretend she's selling
his
services, instead. You can probably guess what happens. She instantly becomes more proactive and confident, simply because she's advocating for someone other than herself.
Chris sums it up nicely:
So, you're more brave for an imaginary relationship that doesn't even exist. Spend some of that energy on yourself. You're worth it.

title.en-US: Chris Do, Maryia Bulka: Raising your prices

description.en-US: Chris Do advices Maryia Bulka on raising her prices.

content.value: That lesson can be applied to our multi-selves strategy. What if every time you binge-watched Netflix instead of getting some work done, the side-effects happened to a friend instead of just to you. Literally picture it: you go on a five-episode tear: they're exhausted and depressed the next day. You resist the urge: they wake up feeling totally energized. Wouldn't that change the decisions you made?

To practice, pick one bad habit that's weighing you down. Imagine how shitty your future self will feel if you do that thing. Even better, say it out loud. How is it going to make them feel? What thoughts will be running through their head? How will they react? Now consider the opposite. What if you make the right choice? How will that affect your future self?
Ok, we're making progress. Now that you've created an emotional connection to one of your future selves, you can apply the same process to other parts of your life. I'll give you a few examples.
Ex. 1: Decaffinating

I love coffee. When I was working as a copywriter in New Jersey, I used to drink 3–4 cups just to make it through the day. It gives you energy, right? Nope. In fact, all caffeine really does is prevent the chemical
adenosine
from binding with your "adenosine receptors"—in other words, it just delays sleepiness. Eventually, that sleepiness will
catch up with you
, making the effects of caffeine completely pointless.

Knowing this wasn't enough to get me to stop drinking coffee. So, I set up a simple experiment to see how coffee actually affected me. A few weeks after going cold turkey, I checked back on my progress. The results were pretty obvious. From February 10th onward, my productivity started to increase dramatically.

title.en-US: Andrew Folts Happiness vs Coffee Chart 2019

content.value: Oftentimes, just
knowing
that something is bad for you isn't enough to outweigh the short-term appeal. Setting a timeline and measuring the actual results can give you extra ammo in your fight for positive change.
Ex. 2: Thinking Rich
"What can I afford?" is a weird question. Weird, because it relates not just to how much money you currently have, but how much you
think
you will have in the future. You might say to yourself: "I want to become a professional photographer. I could
buy
a higher-end camera right now, but I can't
afford
to because it will wipe out my savings, so I'll just buy a cheap one."

There are two problems with this. One, you're going to become dissatisfied with the cheap camera pretty quickly as your skills develop; when you outgrow it and buy the higher-end camera, it will cost you 50% more than if you just bought a more expensive camera to begin with. Two, the things you surround yourself with affect your confidence. If you use a better camera (wear better clothes, eat better food, etc), you will start feeling and
acting like a better person
—just make sure you're investing in things that truly matter to you.

It can help to think about the future self you want to become, then track backwards. What did they do to get to where they are? What products were essential to their success. Would a expert photographer buy a sub-par camera just to save a few bucks? Hell no. They would buy the best camera possible: one they could use for a long time and be inspired by on a daily basis.
Bringing it All Together
Following any of the individual pieces of advice we just covered won't get you very far. But when you use them together, they actually become pretty damn powerful. Let's recap:
1. Imagine your future self

Pick a habit you'd like to start or stop. Describe (in as much detail as you possibly can) how the action you take will affect your future self. Think about what your "past selves" have given you and what you can give that future self.
2. Make the results measurable

You need to prove to yourself that changing this habit will have a positive impact on your life. Setting a timeline (say, two weeks) and tracking a specific effect (productivity, stress, etc) is a great way to motivate yourself.
3. Act more successful than you are

Reverse-engineer your successful future self: how did they get to where they are? What investments or decisions contributed most to their growth? Make a list of 5–10 items, then rewrite the list, ordering them by importance.

title.en-US: Reverse-Engineering 3 Awful Clichés Into Brilliant Life Advice
Reverse-Engineering 3 Awful Clichés Into Brilliant Life Advice

en-US.fileName: Reverse-Engineering 3 Awful Clichés Into Brilliant Life Advice.jpg

summary.en-US: Clichés are the fucking worst. Or are they? I went on a mission to see if I could reverse-engineer some of my least favorites. Here's what happened.

content.value: Clichés are the fucking worst. Or are they? I'm onboard with
Terry Pratchett
's theory:
“The reason that clichés become clichés is that they are the hammers and screwdrivers in the toolbox of communication.”
In other words, clichés become blunt instruments over time. But they must have been insightful at
some
point. Otherwise, why would people have started using them?
That got me thinking. If clichés were once useful, can we still learn from them? I set out to reverse-engineer three of my least favorites. Here's how that panned out.
Fake it 'til you make it

I work a few hours a week at a running store selling shoes, and it's about as low-key as you could ask a part time job to be. But every once in a while, a customer walks in with this certain aura or neuroticism hanging off them—you just KNOW they're going to be a nightmare.
The other day, I had a woman march straight up to the counter and
demand

that someone "fix her feet." She went on to list a string of twenty different ailments (plantar fasciitis, Morton's neuroma, tendinitis...) and wrapped up by asking, accusingly, "Are you any good? Can you help me?" Fucking hell.

Normally, I'd pass off a customer like this to someone with more experience, but, for whatever reason, I just said, "Sure, I can help you." Fifteen minutes later, she walked out of the store having bought the first shoe I pulled—literally beaming with joy over how much better her feet felt. It wasn't anything special. I would have brought the same shoe out for a hundred different customers. So what happened?
For starters, when I said "I can help you," I didn't commit to solving every problem under the sun—I just opened a new avenue in the conversation. In other words, "it's not yet clear
what
I'll be able to help with, but I
do
know that I can move you in a positive direction." This is a hell of a lot less stressful (and perilous) than faking experience you don't have.

Also, it's a ridiculously easy way to become more confident. Most people judge you based on a first impression—so when you answer every new challenge with some form of "yes, and...", you're going to be remembered as a problem-solver (even you end up referring that person to someone else). Case-in-point, consider the two following approaches:
Person A:
"Sorry, I can't help with that. Here's Chris."
Person B:
"Sure, I can help you. Could you tell me more about _____? Ok, I see. I'm going to introduce you to Chris, because he's an expert in _____."
Even though both people have the
same exact
level of experience and provide the
same exact
result, Person B seems way more confident. And they didn't even pretend they knew what they were doing. Crazy, right?
The Takeaway

Don't panic and give up every time an intimidating problem comes your way. If you say "yes" and open the conversation up to learn more, you'll often find that the solution is way simpler than you first expected it to be—that, or you'll realize you already have the skills you thought you were lacking.
That's just the way it is

My Dad likes to play Fifa (soccer) on Xbox 360—it's literally the only video game I've ever gotten him to play. You can check the dusty cardboard graveyard under his TV for further proof: NBA 2K16, Madden 15, NHL 14, WWE SmackDown vs. Raw 2010...you get the picture.
As with every other millennial on the planet, my gaming skills far surpassed my Dad's, so we quickly ran into the trivial (but surprisingly annoying) problem of which difficulty level to play on.

"Semi-Pro" was too easy for me: every time I got the ball, I would just dribble around the doped-down AI players like Ronaldo schooling a bunch of firth-graders from the local rec league. We won every game. Conversely, "Professional" was too much for my Dad to handle. After a four or five-game losing streak, he would inevitably chuck his controller onto the couch or wax dejectedly about how "the computer" (what he calls any technology that's not a microwave or a fridge) was "out to get us."

Like I said, a super-trivial problem. But, then again, it felt like a metaphor for a bigger conflict: the fact that I was in the "grinding" phase of my life (chasing big goals, working eighty hours a week, and growing multiple businesses) while my Dad was in the "coasting" phase of his life (reading, watching the British Baking Show, and making art on his own schedule).

We were trapped in a "that's just the way it is" mentality, equally unsatisfied by our present options, and desperately wishing for the Xbox gods to bestow upon us a "Sort-of-Professional" difficulty level, that would have been—at best—a slightly less terrible compromise.

One day, it occurred to me that, instead of waiting for the game to change, we could simply write our own rules. So, I introduced the following plan: we would play on "Semi-Pro," but if we scored three goals or more, we would play the next match on "Professional." If we lost or tied on Professional, we would move back down to Semi-Pro...and so forth.

The new rules were a wild success. For one, I now felt like I had something to play for on Semi-Pro—scoring more goals was harder, and, thus, I didn't have to dumb-down my play. Secondly, and more interestingly, my Dad started playing really well on Professional. It wasn't the difficulty level that he got frustrated by before, but, rather, the lack of a comfort zone. If we were playing poorly, the disappointment felt endless to him. With the new rules, he always had Semi-Pro to fall back on, even though we started playing well enough to hardly ever need it.
The Takeaway
Our brains love to get stuck in
faulty logic loops

, which make us feel like we've exhausted all possible solutions. What you need to do is redefine the problem. In my case, I assumed that, because the game only allowed one difficulty setting at a time, my Dad and I both had to play on the same level. This wasn't true. Once I let go of that assumption, I was able to come up with a solution that benefited both of us equally—instead of just settling for a shitty compromise.
You have to put yourself out there

Over the past couple months, I've been moving all the custom-coded websites I built as a freelance developer over to Squarespace. It was a no-brainer for most of my clients because their sites weren't that complex and using a website builder gives a non-techy person way more freedom to make changes themselves—plus I was offering to do it for free. Nice, right?

Weirdly, I got a lot of pushback. One client, in particular, threw a total curve ball by ghosting me for weeks, then suddenly hiring a totally unqualified IT "professional" to manage the existing website (his own site looked like it had stepped out of a time machine from 1992). This is
insane
, I thought. Everything will be exactly the same on Squarespace, except they'll pay a lot less and have more control. Who wouldn't want that?

After multiple emails back and forth—this only created more confusion—it finally occurred to me to pick up the phone and actually call my client. (How millennial of me.) Unsurprisingly, we cleared everything up in thirty seconds.

Back when I sent the first email, my client assumed that, because I wasn't providing maintenance anymore, she needed to hire a new "webmaster." (A lot of small businesses still think this is a thing.) She literally didn't know a service existed that could allow her to edit a website herself. Once I explained how it worked, she got on board instantly.

What's this got to do with "putting yourself out there," you ask? As an introvert, I naturally associate the words "out there" with attending schmaltzy networking events and forcing myself to socialize with people I hate. But I think what the phrase actually means is figuring out which course of action is the most likely to help you achieve a desired result.

When I told my client about moving her site to Squarespace, that was a knowledge bomb. I was afraid she might take it the wrong way, which is precisely why I should have just called her in the first place—talking to someone allows you to provide emotional support and catch confusion before it morphs into a bigger problem. Ironically, the reason why we
should
do something and the reason why we
don't
are often connected.
The Takeaway

Thinking of "putting yourself out there" as a chore is a huge mistake. What you want to do is snatch negative thought processes in mid air ("this call could be a difficult call, so I'll just email"), and pinpoint a positive opportunity ("calling my client will make things clear and save time"). You can apply this to virtually any situation.

For example, one of my longterm goals is to make a living at writing. I "write" in my head constantly—this is technically a medium, but not a very useful one for earning money. So, one level at a time, I expanded what "out there" meant to me: I started writing my ideas down (to not forget them), I stored them in Notion (for organization), I created a blog (to get them where they can actually be read), and began promoting them (so people know my writing exists). Pretty soon, I'll launch a podcast...and the list goes on, until I'm making a certain amount of money. Then I'll set new goals and figure out where I need to "put myself" to make them happen. Where do you need to put yourself?
Clichés: Eliminated

Oh man, that was cathartic. As much as I hate clichés, I think they're a gold mine for insight if you take a little time to reverse-engineer them. What are your top three least favorites? Tweet 'em to me
@fthelines
or join the convo on
Reddit

title.en-US: 10 Million You's: The Hidden Benefits of Dying Every Day

summary.en-US: Making the right decisions every day is hard. A simple trick you can easily implement is dividing each moment into different "selves," aka dying.

content.value: It was the sushi that killed me. In that first bite, I suddenly realized that I was dead. And not only that—I was about to die again.
Ok, that intro was super-harsh. Let me rewind a bit.
Theseus
While I was going to
Ithaca

for my first two years of college, I developed this addiction to philosophy. Even then, I knew it was pretty much useless (in the sense of directly repaying my $50k of student loan debt). But I couldn't help myself.
I was particularly interested in thought experiments: outlandish scenarios that philosophers devise to illustrate a certain problem or theory. One of my all-time favorites is the
Ship of Theseus
. It goes something like this:

Suppose a ship sailed by the Greek hero Theseus is kept in a harbor as a museum piece. Over time, some of the wooden parts begin to rot—and after a century or so, all of the parts have been replaced. Is it still the "same" ship?
This is a direct analogy to human identity, aka: "Am I the same person I was ten years ago? Will I be the same person in twenty years?" The comfortable answer is
yes
, but I'm going to ask you to do something strange. I'm going to ask you to start dying with me. Ready? Let's do this.
The Day of a Thousand Deaths

Back to the sushi. I don't normally make profound existential discoveries while eating seaweed and rice, but on this particular Friday, I was late to work, and those sushi rolls were literally the only thing standing between me and a four-hour shift of selling shoes on an empty stomach.

Back then (ok, you got me...it was like a year ago), I was cooking spaghetti for 50% of my dinners and rarely making more than a single serving at a time, so it was a pleasant surprise to find myself pre-stocked for once.

In that moment, I felt a kind of gratitude—not to "myself," but to a former version of myself who had spent time to make the sushi. That Andrew (yesterday at 5pm Andrew) would never get to enjoy the fruits of his labor. He had sacrificed short-term pleasure to make life better for a future self.

It was weirdly heroic. And that feeling of heroism (I'll call it "self-patriotism") changed how I looked at my life. By separating myself into many "selves" that were constantly dying and being born in every moment, I gained a deeper respect for how my decisions affected the person I would become.
Like Ryan Gosling in
Blade Runner 2049
, when you decide to start giving up meaningless in-the-moment temptations, it allows you to shift your entire life into a higher gear—to live for a greater purpose.
Dying for the right cause is the most human thing we can do.

title.en-US: Blade Runner 2049: Dying for the right cause

description.en-US: Blade Runner 2049: Dying for the right cause is the most human thing we can do.

content.value: Becoming a Self-Patriot
I think you'll probably agree that it's easier to advocate for someone else than to stand up for yourself. I'm reminded of
this video
, where Maryia Bulka (an artist/designer) is struggling to raise her prices.
Chris Do (a business coach) asks her to pretend she's selling
his
services, instead. You can probably guess what happens. She instantly becomes more proactive and confident, simply because she's advocating for someone other than herself.
Chris sums it up nicely:
So, you're more brave for an imaginary relationship that doesn't even exist. Spend some of that energy on yourself. You're worth it.

title.en-US: Chris Do, Maryia Bulka: Raising your prices

description.en-US: Chris Do advices Maryia Bulka on raising her prices.

content.value: That lesson can be applied to our multi-selves strategy. What if every time you binge-watched Netflix instead of getting some work done, the side-effects happened to a friend instead of just to you. Literally picture it: you go on a five-episode tear: they're exhausted and depressed the next day. You resist the urge: they wake up feeling totally energized. Wouldn't that change the decisions you made?

To practice, pick one bad habit that's weighing you down. Imagine how shitty your future self will feel if you do that thing. Even better, say it out loud. How is it going to make them feel? What thoughts will be running through their head? How will they react? Now consider the opposite. What if you make the right choice? How will that affect your future self?
Ok, we're making progress. Now that you've created an emotional connection to one of your future selves, you can apply the same process to other parts of your life. I'll give you a few examples.
Ex. 1: Decaffinating

I love coffee. When I was working as a copywriter in New Jersey, I used to drink 3–4 cups just to make it through the day. It gives you energy, right? Nope. In fact, all caffeine really does is prevent the chemical
adenosine
from binding with your "adenosine receptors"—in other words, it just delays sleepiness. Eventually, that sleepiness will
catch up with you
, making the effects of caffeine completely pointless.

Knowing this wasn't enough to get me to stop drinking coffee. So, I set up a simple experiment to see how coffee actually affected me. A few weeks after going cold turkey, I checked back on my progress. The results were pretty obvious. From February 10th onward, my productivity started to increase dramatically.

title.en-US: Andrew Folts Happiness vs Coffee Chart 2019

content.value: Oftentimes, just
knowing
that something is bad for you isn't enough to outweigh the short-term appeal. Setting a timeline and measuring the actual results can give you extra ammo in your fight for positive change.
Ex. 2: Thinking Rich
"What can I afford?" is a weird question. Weird, because it relates not just to how much money you currently have, but how much you
think
you will have in the future. You might say to yourself: "I want to become a professional photographer. I could
buy
a higher-end camera right now, but I can't
afford
to because it will wipe out my savings, so I'll just buy a cheap one."

There are two problems with this. One, you're going to become dissatisfied with the cheap camera pretty quickly as your skills develop; when you outgrow it and buy the higher-end camera, it will cost you 50% more than if you just bought a more expensive camera to begin with. Two, the things you surround yourself with affect your confidence. If you use a better camera (wear better clothes, eat better food, etc), you will start feeling and
acting like a better person
—just make sure you're investing in things that truly matter to you.

It can help to think about the future self you want to become, then track backwards. What did they do to get to where they are? What products were essential to their success. Would a expert photographer buy a sub-par camera just to save a few bucks? Hell no. They would buy the best camera possible: one they could use for a long time and be inspired by on a daily basis.
Bringing it All Together
Following any of the individual pieces of advice we just covered won't get you very far. But when you use them together, they actually become pretty damn powerful. Let's recap:
1. Imagine your future self

Pick a habit you'd like to start or stop. Describe (in as much detail as you possibly can) how the action you take will affect your future self. Think about what your "past selves" have given you and what you can give that future self.
2. Make the results measurable

You need to prove to yourself that changing this habit will have a positive impact on your life. Setting a timeline (say, two weeks) and tracking a specific effect (productivity, stress, etc) is a great way to motivate yourself.
3. Act more successful than you are

Reverse-engineer your successful future self: how did they get to where they are? What investments or decisions contributed most to their growth? Make a list of 5–10 items, then rewrite the list, ordering them by importance.

title.en-US: Creative Block Almost Killed Me: Here's How You Can Slay It

summary.en-US: The following is a story about how creative block nearly killed me. And even more importantly, five steps you can use to annihilate it for good.

content.value: How many times have you Googled the phrase "creative block" in your life? How many times this month? This week? I've lost count. And judging by the 930 million results that search returns, being stuck (creatively) is a problem that a bunch of other people are struggling with, too. It fucking sucks. I know.
The Downward Spiral

Back in July of 2016, I was living at home—I had impulsively quit my full-time job as a copywriter earlier that year to start my own design company. Things were going pretty well, and I was taking on every project that came my way.
One of my clients was looking to publish an illustrated book at the time, so naturally I said yes. Mind you, I was a web designer, and hadn't
really
illustrated much of anything, let alone designed an entire book. But screw it. I can totally do this!

Shocker...a few weeks into the project, it was starting to feel like I totally could NOT "do this." I was overwhelmed by all the things I needed to learn in order to deliver the final product, but there was an even bigger problem: creative block had set in—badly. Just sitting down at the computer was painful. My illustrations looked like shit (to me), and the harder I tried to find inspiration, the more resistant my brain became to providing any kind of creative energy.

Around the same time, my cousin-in-law (who I had just seen in Utah) was placed in hospice and a family friend committed suicide, which was the final straw. I fell into total burnout mode: ignoring emails, playing video games, binging TV series, reading design "inspiration" articles, and arguing mindlessly about politics on Reddit 24/7. Basically, doing anything and everything I could think of to jump start my creative process.
This culminated in what I can only describe as "the worst day of my life."

I hadn't eaten anything or moved from my spot on the living room for the past five hours. I hadn't talked to anyone or left the house in...fuck, I have no clue how long. My phone was on, but only because I knew that if I turned it off someone would think I was dead—which would mean police. Which would mean interacting with the outside world.

Around that time, a car pulled into the driveway. I remember my first thought being, "Oh shit...THEY FOUND ME." Which is kind of funny in retrospect, because, like...who did I think was after me? I was a designer running late on a small illustration project, not Tom Cruise dodging taser-wielding agents in
Minority Report
I high-tailed it to my room, and put some serious thought to
jumping

hopping out the back window. It wasn't the cops (taser-wielding or otherwise). It turned out to be my ex-professor/creative partner's son, who she had sent over to check on me. Nonetheless, I knew there would be more humans where that one came from...none of whom I cared to confront, let alone carry out a conversation with.

I threw my bike in the back of my car and headed over to the local library. Why the library, you ask? Well, the plan, as I recall, was to drop my car off at the nearest parking lot then bike back to my house so I could make it look like I wasn't home and buy some time while I gathered any essential belongings that would be accompanying me on my escape to the forest, where I would live happily ever after and never wrestle with creativity again.
It was a beautiful plan.

Sadly, or maybe fortunately, I didn't make it two blocks before a cop car rolled around the corner and flagged me down. Like Tom Cruise, I was ready to fucking run. But I somehow managed to play it cool (enough).
No, I hadn't realized people were trying to get in touch with me for weeks...yes, I'll call them back...me, I'm fine...oh, the bike? I was just...uh, going for a bike...ride...nice day, isn't it?

The cop eventually drove off, and I was left idling in the middle of the road—a fitting metaphor for my current outlook on life. I started mentally backpedaling though the chain of events that had led to this moment. Like
Theoden trapped at Helm's Deep
, beset by a massive army of Uruk-hai, desolately wondering: "How did it come to this?" And more importantly, what was I going to do about it?

title.en-US: Theoden: How did it come to this?

content.value: The Road Back
I wish I could say I learned a hard, swift lesson from that experience. But the truth is, while I did start to take my mental/emotional
health
wellbeing more seriously, creative block continued to haunt me on a daily basis, and it took the better part of three years to distill my mistakes into an effective solution.
That's what I'm going to share with you now: a bullet-proof, battle-tested strategy to slay creative block once and for all.
Step 1: Define Creative Block
"To defeat your enemy, you must first know your enemy." —Sun Tzu
Actually, Sun Tzu didn't say that. But it sounds like something he might say, and I don't want to get sidetracked by Googling a real quote right now. (We're trying to stay creative, remember?)
You see, I think people get
wayyy
to fancy with their definition of creative block: it's a lack of inspiration, it's self-doubt, it's negative self-talk, it's rejection anxiety...
Fuck all that. I'll tell you what creative block is; it's very simple:
Creative block is a shortage of mental energy that results from consistently inputting more than you output.

This is a highly effective place to start when diagnosing your creative woes. Try saying it out loud: "I am tired and uncreative because I have input more that I have output today." How did that feel? Does the problem seem slightly more manageable now? Good, let's keep going.
Step 2: List Your Mental Earning and Spending

I used to think that my brain was magical—that I had an unlimited supply of energy, which could be drawn upon endlessly without fail. This was/is clearly not true. So, when you try to understand what's causing your creative block, it can be really helpful to divide your day-to-day activities into two categories: mental earning and mental spending.
Mental Earning:

the act of producing or changing something. Designing a landing page, writing a blog post, playing the drums, or even organizing your room. By definition, you have been creative by doing one of these things—there is an immediate benefit.
Mental Spending:

refers to passive stuff, like watching YouTube videos, browsing Reddit, listening to a podcast, or shopping on Amazon. You may pick up inspiration from these things, but they don't benefit you until you act on that inspiration.

Now that you're aware of these two categories, what I want you to do is grab a piece of paper and write down all the things that give you energy on one side and all the things that drain your energy on the other side. Here are a few of mine:

title.en-US: My energy draining and giving activities

content.value: Step 3: Shed the Dead Weight
Ok, you've got your list. Next, you're going to
Marie Kondo
this list by killing off anything that's not helping you progress as a creative human. For each item on the "Draining" side of your list, ask yourself one question:
Does this thing
actually
make my life better, or does it just
feel
that way?

When going through this process, it's essential to only consider the cold hard facts because "sugary" addictions will try to justify their existence in very sneaky ways. For example, when I stopped using dating apps, I could hear this little voice in my head protesting: "But you're missing out on all these opportunities to meet people!"

Dating apps make us feel good in the moment by showing lots of pictures of attractive people (it's basically micro-porn). But over the past three years, I've probably spent hundreds of hours on Tinder, OkCupid, et al., and I have only one very mediocre date to show for it. I've literally gotten better results by hanging out at my local climbing gym for five minutes!

When you add up how much time these "feel-good" pursuits suck up on a daily basis (with no tangible benefits) it's absolutely staggering. That's why you need to be super-ruthless in hunting them down and jettisoning them from your life before they suck you dry. Take your list and nail it to the wall, if necessary!
Step 4: Redefine "Creative" and "Output"
You're familiar with the
punishing inner critic

, right? It's that little voice in your head that says    everything you create is garbage and everything you accomplish is not enough. Well, if you're really serious about sticking to the list you just made, you need to confront that voice—or it's  going to keep making you miserable.

The simplest way to disarm your inner critic is to redefine the words "creative" and "output." Firstly, let's expand the kind of work we deem to be creative. I'm not advising you to lower your ambitions, but, rather, to take note of the many small wins that would normally fly under the radar.

Say you're spinning your wheels on a logo design—it feels like you haven't done anything creative all day. Instead of comparing that work against the best logo you've ever made, readjust your mental "zoom" to only cover the designs you're currently working on. From that perspective, one or two iterations will stand out as more creative than the others. And, voila! You've suddenly "done" something creative by retroactively changing your standards. You can then use that small rush of inspiration to slingshot you toward an even better iteration.

Similarly, you're not going to have the same level of energy every day, so it's emotionally toxic to expect the same level of output at all times. If you find yourself mentally exhausted before you've finished breakfast (the struggle is real), scale back the list of things you want to accomplish. You might end up doing more than you thought you could, and adding extra items to a to-do list is way more empowering than struggling to complete one that feels like it's a mile long.
Step 5: Stay Vigilant

Money is much easier to spend than earn; your brain is no different. If want to keep creative block at bay, you need to be mindful of the different ways that it can slither back into your life. It's like Mad-Eye Moody says: "Constant vigilance!" I think there are basically four ways to do this—although feel free to adopt more strategies as you go.
Emotional Zagging

Disappointment and frustration are the two of the biggest culprits behind creative block. When I started to feel trapped by the illustration project, I should have taken a breather to assess the situation and figure out what the best course of action was. Instead, I pushed myself to the point of emotional burnout, then went on a mental spending tear to try and distract from the pain of creative block.

Now, whenever I get a pang of anxiety, I do an "emotional zag," which essentially means taking negative energy and using it to slingshot you in an opposite (positive) direction. Energy is energy, after all. So, when I feel the urge to erase an especially brutal round of logo revisions by aimlessly swiping on Tinder, I go straight out for a run instead.
Stick to the Mission

UX design has made the platforms and apps we use so fucking "convenient" that a five-second search on Google can (and will) turn into three hours of binge-watching cat videos on YouTube. Always, ALWAYS, have a singular, achievable mission when you dive into social media. Once you find the information you need, bail
immediately
. You can even set a timer on your phone and write your objective down on a piece of paper, if necessary.
Maintain an Input / Output Ratio

I find I'm the happiest and most creative when I spend 90% of my time creating and 10% learning or browsing for inspiration—anything below 75% is getting into the danger zone. When you find a balance that works for you, post it on your wall or somewhere you'll see it often. Do a mental check throughout the day to make sure you're in the clear.
Create Your Own Rulebook
I have a Daily Log database in
Notion

(more on this in another post) where I track personal stats, one of those being a "Rules Broken" field that lists any personal rules that I broke that day—No screens after 10pm, Get out of bed instantly, etc. You don't have to get this fancy; your rule log might just be a simple list scrawled on the back cover of your notebook. But whichever method you choose, keeping track of your slip-ups can help you see when something is becoming a negative pattern.
Alright, that's it.

You now have all the weapons you need to slay creative block for good. It won't be easy, but if you follow these five steps, you'll be amazed by how quickly it slithers back to the dark, dismal hole it came from. If you want to drop a comment or question, head over to the article link on Reddit. Be well, everyone.
Last week, I kicked off a

description.en-US: A series of weekly articles with the goal of publishing a simple framework anyone can use to design and create an unconventional life.

teaser.en-US: Get weekly insights sent straight to your inbox. No bullshit, just 100% actionable advice.

content.value: fifteen-part series

to answer one burning question: how the hell do I create a business that allows me to quit my job and start living the life I want? A lot of people want to know the answer to that question—but, frankly, I don't think we're going to get it from finance gurus or millionaire "lifestyle" coaches. We need to go out and earn the solution through curiosity, gutsiness, and hard work.
Are you game for that? Alright, let's do this.
If we're going to fuck with the lines, if we're going to chase true freedom, we need a solid plan—a blueprint for the life we want to create.
Part 1: Preparation

What we're about to do is not easy. It's going to take both time and emotional energy, so you need to carve out some space in your life. If you try to create a plan for change while surrounded by distractions, you're going to end up right back where you started.

So break out the camping gear, book a motel, or take a drive to your local park. You should dedicate, at minimum, 4–8 hours to go through the process and allow any insights to fully percolate. If you can spare a whole weekend you should, but work with what you've got.

Also, make sure you've taken care of any prior commitments before embarking on your mini sabbatical. The last thing you want is to be stressing the whole time or to get interrupted half way through. Turn your phone off—better yet, leave it at home.

We're going to be doing a fair amount of writing, so you'll want to pick the medium that works best for you. I'm a fan of writing in a journal or on loose paper, but you can draft your blueprint in Word, Google Docs, or even
Notion
if you're more digitally inclined. Just make sure you get all this stuff out of your head and onto a page.
To recap...
Set aside 4–8 hours (ideally, a weekend)
Get FAR away from distractions
Take care of any commitments beforehand
Choose the writing tools that work the best for you
Part 2: Knowing Yourself
First, before galavanting off to set some crazy-ambitious goals, you need to know who you are. "Me? I know who I am!" Ok,
Robert Downey Jr. in Tropic Thunder
, you may THINK you know, but let's just be sure so we don't build this blueprint on false assumptions.

title.en-US: Robert Downey Jr. in Tropic Thunder: "I'm a dude!"

content.value: Making Your Flow List

What we're going to do is create a list of 20–30 "flow moments." These are times in your life when you felt the most free—when creativity and happiness came effortlessly, and you were completely in the moment.
They don't have to be in any specific order, just write down whatever comes to mind first (your strongest memories). Here are a few of mine:
Coming up with the idea for F the Lines
Stargazing under a blanket with a girl in college
Talking with a mentor about our creative aspirations
Finding Your Archetypes

Now that you've made your list, the next step is assigning an "archetype" to each memory. Don't worry, we're not going to get all wu wu here, the goal is just to define the different aspects of your identity—what motivates you?
Technically, psychiatrist
Carl Jung

came up with the twelve archetypes we'll be using, but you'll recognize them as characters from movies, books, stories, etc, and even people in your day-to-day life. They're pretty self-explanatory, but if you want to dive deeper,
The Hero and The Outlaw
by Carol Pearson is a great read. I also created a handy
table
with all the key points.
Ok, onward!
For each item on your flow list, write down which of the following archetypes most closely fits that memory. You can only pick ONE archetype per memory.
Ruler:
exert control
Creator:
craft something new
Sage:
understand your world
Innocent:
retain or renew faith
Explorer:
maintain independence
Outlaw:
break the rules
Hero:
act courageously
Magician:
affect transformation
Jester:
have a good time
Regular Guy/Gal:
be ok just as you are
Lover:
find and give love
Caregiver:
care for others
Ranking Your Archetypes
Alright, now make a tally of your top archetypes and sort that list according to the number of flow moments. Here's what mine looks like:
Creator:
Lover:
Explorer:
Sage:
Magician:
Jester:
Hero:
Defining What You Stand For

Excellent. So you know which archetypes make up your collective identity, but what do they actually mean to you? What beliefs and values will you stand for when the going gets rough and you need to make big decisions?
For each of your top five archetypes (the fewer the better), write three words that describe how you will implement it in your life. This is how I mapped out my "Creator" archetype:
Minimalism:
using the fewest resources possible
Sustainability:
creating a better future vs indulging short-term
Originality:
giving new ideas to the world
Finished with your list? Nice job.
Crafting a Life Statement
The point of all this isn't just to understand your personality type—you can do that with a
BuzzFeed quiz
. (Don't click that link, we've got work to do...I'm testing you!) What we want to do is figure out which parts of our identity are in conflict.

I've been working eighty-hour weeks for the past few years, hustling to build a freelance business, and I let my love life fall by the wayside. I thought that was fine, but, (judging by my own list) it's clearly not, and I need to find a way to get my need for independence (The Explorer) to mesh with my desire for intimacy (The Lover).
The best way to iron out
cognitive dissonance
is to write a sentence—it will literally force you bring conflicting words together. Think of it as a
positioning statement
for your life. You don't need to get fancy, just identify the problem and write a straightforward solution that incorporates your top archetypes. Here's what I came up with for
Creator
Lover
Explorer
Sage
Magician
I am a creator who seeks out deep intimacy with other open-minded people and cultivates freedom through shared knowledge and inspiration.

I've now made intimacy a priority and attached it to a mission of "seeking" open-minded people, which is basically a target audience. I'm also going to focus on becoming more free and helping other people do the same, which feels way less boring than trying to "network more" or "go on more dates."
What did you come up with?
Tweet it to me
Part 3: Setting Goals
You're still with me. You didn't click on that BuzzFeed quiz and get sidetracked like
Sir Robin at the Bridge of Death
. Good. We'll go far together.

Now that you know your archetypes and you've distilled those archetypes into a pithy life statement, it's time to set some goals. Ideally, we want to filter these goals into as few "ventures" as humanly possible to focus our efforts.

You probably have a lot of ventures going already. For example, I'm a drummer. I'd love to go on tour and release an album, but my #1 priority right now is figuring out how to create a business that sets me free—I need to concentrate on that goal.

If you can find a way to bundle multiple ventures together, great. Otherwise, the less important ones need to go on the back burner. And believe me when I say: you must be ruthless in cutting out anything that's not essential to your mission, because it will take more time and energy than you can possibly imagine. Here's where I landed:
F the Lines:
create a "freedom business"
Sherpa Design Co.:
make money in the short-term
Relationships:
meet people, seek out intimacy
Defining Your Ventures

For each of these ventures, you're going to write two paragraphs. In the first, you're going to describe "Where I am." This is a no-bullshit analysis of your present situation. What have you accomplished? What are you struggling with? What are you unsure about? What roadblocks are stopping you from moving forward?
This is an abridged version of what I wrote for my F the Lines venture:
Where I Am:

I've posted a few articles, I but haven't officially launched yet. I don't have a following, or even know whether F the Lines will be interesting/helpful to other people. My website isn't finished, and I need to record an intro video/podcast to launch the project. I'm interested in writing a book and possibly doing some coaching, but I'm not entirely sure how I'm going to make money.

In the second paragraph, you're going to write down "Where I want to be." Paint a picture of the exact life you want—limit your thinking to the next 1–10 years. I'm keeping my examples brief, but the more defined you can make your ambitions, the more likely you are to succeed. Go to town—really let your imagination run wild. Remember...
Fuzzy goals = fuzzy results
Where I Want to Be:

I want to start a podcast and interview other creative entrepreneurs. I want to start making some money on Medium to verify that people actually get value from my content. I want to transition to FTL full time by the end of 2020. I want to help other creatives learn how to build a "freedom business" that allows them to escape the 9–5 world or unsatisfying service industry jobs. I want to buy a travel van and live on the road.

Next, extract any major milestones from your paragraph and turn them into a bulleted list under each venture. Don't worry about the order yet, we're going to get to that in just a second. Some of the goals I wrote down for F the Lines...
Make $100,000/year
Buy and convert a Ford Transit Connect van
Go on a "van life" road trip to Maine
Start a podcast and interview creative entrepreneurs
Offer business and life coaching sessions
Prioritizing Your Goals
Alright, my friend. We're in the home stretch. I borrowed this last technique from
7 Strategies for Wealth & Happiness
by Jim Rohn. The book is a bit cheesy, but the concepts are pure gold, and you should read it if you want a quick way to learn more about goal-setting and personal finance.

Take a look at each goal for your three ventures and write down when you think you can accomplish it by. Don't worry about guessing wrong—you can always adjust later, but the important part is to get some dates down.

Once you've done that, split the goals up by timeframe and reorder them by importance. For example: one month, six months, one year, two years, five years, etc. It can help to do this part in an Excel spreadsheet or, ideally, an app like Notion that allows you to set reminders. That way, you can quickly reorder your goals, instead of rewriting them over and over.

Take a look at each chunk of time. If you have a lot of goals in the "One Month" section, but only a few in "One Year" and "Five Years," you might need to revisit your "Where I Want to Be" paragraphs and spend some more time describing the life you're trying to create.
If you have a shortage of short-term goals, that's ok. We're going to cover creating a productivity system and mapping out fine-grained tasks in the next two articles of the

teaser.en-US: Get weekly insights sent straight to your inbox. No bullshit, just 100% actionable advice.

content.value: Framework Journey series
Next Week: Saving Resources
Congrats, seriously. That was a lot of work. As you might have guessed, this is just the first step toward actually creating a new kind of life, but I'm feeling good. How about you?

description.en-US: GIF of Will Ferrell punching the cereal isle and screaming "awesome."

content.value: Ah...you're stoked to keep making progress. Excellent. Before we can really go to town on our goals, though, we have to free up the resources we need to make it happen. That's why, next week, we're going to be talking about SAVING—saving money, saving time, and saving energy. We've got to make sure there's enough fuel in the tank, otherwise we're not leaving the driveway.
So look out for that email. The subject line is "FTL / Week 2: Saving Money & Energy." If you're not already subscribed to the Framework Journey series, you can

to get weekly updates with 100% actionable advice.
